column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=THE RELUCTANT DRAGON
#Text=Footprints in the snow have been unfailing provokers of sentiment ever since snow was first a white wonder in this drab-coloured world of ours .

#Text=In a poetry-book presented to one of us by an aunt , there was a poem by one Wordsworth in which they stood out strongly -- with a picture all to themselves , too -- but we did n't think very highly either of the poem or the sentiment .
#Text=Footprints in the sand , now , were quite another matter , and we grasped Crusoe 's attitude of mind much more easily than Wordsworth 's .
#Text=Excitement and mystery , curiosity and suspense -- these were the only sentiments that tracks , whether in sand or in snow , were able to arouse in us .
#Text=We had awakened early that winter morning , puzzled at first by the added light that filled the room .

#Text=Then , when the truth at last fully dawned on us and we knew that snow-balling was no longer a wistful dream , but a solid certainty waiting for us outside , it was a mere brute fight for the necessary clothes , and the lacing of boots seemed a clumsy invention , and the buttoning of coats an unduly tedious form of fastening , with all that snow going to waste at our very door .
#Text=When dinner-time came we had to be dragged in by the scruff of our necks .

#Text=The short armistice over , the combat was resumed ; but presently Charlotte and I , a little weary of contests and of missiles that ran shudderingly down inside one 's clothes , forsook the trampled battle-field of the lawn and went exploring the blank virgin spaces of the white world that lay beyond .
#Text=It stretched away unbroken on every side of us , this mysterious soft garment under which our familiar world had so suddenly hidden itself .
#Text=Faint imprints showed where a casual bird had alighted , but of other traffic there was next to no sign ; which made these strange tracks all the more puzzling .
#Text=We came across them first at the corner of the shrubbery , and pored over them long , our hands on our knees .
#Text=Experienced trappers that we knew ourselves to be , it was annoying to be brought up suddenly by a beast we could not at once identify .
#Text=“ Do n't you know ? ” said Charlotte , rather scornfully .
#Text=“ Thought you knew all the beasts that ever was . ”
#Text=This put me on my mettle , and I hastily rattled off a string of animal names embracing both the arctic and the tropic zones , but without much real confidence .
#Text=“ No , ” said Charlotte , on consideration ;
#Text=“ they wo n't any of ' em quite do .
#Text=Seems like something LIZARDY .
#Text=Did you say a iguanodon ?
#Text=Might be that , p'raps .
#Text=But that 's not British , and we want a real British beast .
#Text=I think it 's a dragon ! ”
#Text=“ ' T is n't half big enough , ” I objected .
#Text=“ Well , all dragons must be small to begin with , ” said Charlotte :
#Text=“ like everything else .
#Text=P'raps this is a little dragon who 's got lost .
#Text=A little dragon would be rather nice to have .
#Text=He might scratch and spit , but he could n't DO anything really .
#Text=Let 's track him down ! ”
#Text=So we set off into the wide snow-clad world , hand in hand , our hearts big with expectation , -- complacently confident that by a few smudgy traces in the snow
#Text=we were in a fair way to capture a half-grown specimen of a fabulous beast .
#Text=We ran the monster across the paddock and along the hedge of the next field , and then he took to the road like any tame civilized tax-payer .

#Text=Here his tracks became blended with and lost among more ordinary footprints , but imagination and a fixed idea will do a great deal , and we were sure we knew the direction a dragon would naturally take .

#Text=The traces , too , kept reappearing at intervals -- at least Charlotte maintained they did , and as it was HER dragon I left the following of the slot to her and trotted along peacefully , feeling that it was an expedition anyhow and something was sure to come out of it .

#Text=Charlotte took me across another field or two , and through a copse , and into a fresh road ; and I began to feel sure it was only her confounded pride that made her go on pretending to see dragon-tracks instead of owning she was entirely at fault , like a reasonable person .

#Text=At last she dragged me excitedly through a gap in a hedge of an obviously private character ; the waste , open world of field and hedge-row disappeared , and we found ourselves in a garden , well-kept , secluded , most un-dragon-haunted in appearance .
#Text=Once inside , I knew where we were .
#Text=This was the garden of my friend the circus-man , though I had never approached it before by a lawless gap , from this unfamiliar side .
#Text=And here was the circus-man himself , placidly smoking a pipe as he strolled up and down the walks .
#Text=I stepped up to him and asked him politely if he had lately seen a Beast .
#Text=“ May I inquire , ” he said , with all civility , “ what particular sort of a Beast you may happen to be looking for ? ”
#Text=“ It 's a LIZARDY sort of Beast , ” I explained .
#Text=“ Charlotte says it 's a dragon , but she does n't really know much about beasts . ”
#Text=The circus-man looked round about him slowly .
#Text=“ I do n't THINK , ” he said , “ that I 've seen a dragon in these parts recently .
#Text=But if I come across one I 'll know it belongs to you , and I 'll have him taken round to you at once . ”
